text: TIGHT ON THE FACE OF JAMIE MCALLAN (Caucasian, 20's) Black eye. Cut lip. He looks like a beaten prize fighter who is dripping in sweat and mud. WIDEN TO REVEAL we are.

The ash colored storm clouds make it look like night. Jam scrapes the muck off his shovel blade and resumes. The mu is so thick it’s like digging into raw meat. A distant lightning flash accompanied by THUNDER. Jamie u his urgency as he chops at the wet earth. An upside down face appears in the hole’s opening. It’s HENRY MCALLAN (Caucasian, late 40's), Jamie’s salt-of-the-earth, older brother. Henry is a man of few words who rarely smiles. They speak with the lilting garble of the Mississippi Del
My turn. Take a break.
We ain’t gonna make it.

We will. We have to. Henry extends his hand and helps Jamie out of the hole. Then, as Henry maneuvers his way into the hole we see tha moves with a noticeable limp. Jamie pulls a handkerchief from his pocket and wipes mud from his face and hands. As watches Henry dig we hear Jamie’s VOICE OVER:

We will. We have to. That was my brother, Henry: absolutely certain whatever he wanted to happen would. The weather would dry out in time to resow the cotton. Next year would be a better year. We would get this hole dug before the storm hit. (beat) And his little brother would never betray him. LIGHTNING and THUNDER. Jamie looks up and sees angry, bla clouds eating up the sky. Then from inside the hole we he a CLANG as Henry’s shovel hits something hard.
Dammit.
What is it?

Piece of rock, I think. Henry shoves his hand into the mud to pull out the rock. what he retrieves is actually a human skull missing a big chunk in the back. They trade a look. Henry keeps digging alternating between shovel and bare hands as he discovers rest of the skeleton. A collarbone, scapula and ribs.

No, no, no. Oh Lord... It ain’t right. This just ain’t right. Henry digs out the pelvis and leg bones. We hear a metall CLINK. Henry unearths the tibia and sees a crude, rusted iron shackle with a broken chain dangling from it.
Jesus. This is a slave’s grave.
You don’t know that.
See here? Shot in the head. Must’ve been a runaway. (extending a grimy hand) That settles it. Help me out.
Settles what?
I won’t bury our father in a slave’s grave. There’s nothing he would’ve hated more.
We don’t have a choice. More LIGHTNING and THUNDER. The brothers hold a look. Henry knows Jamie is right.
The hole has grown longer and deeper and is now a foot ov Jamie's head - a proper grave. Henry’s face appears in th opening of the hole:

Yep, that should do it. Jamie hands the shovel up. But then, when Henry tries to help Jamie out, it’s no use. The hole is too deep, their hands are too wet and the walls are too slick. HENRY (CONT’D) I'll fetch the ladder. Jamie nods and Henry moves off. As the squelch of Henry's boots steadily grows quiet we see the pain and worry in Jamie's eyes. All around him is oozing mud. And overhead a crude rectangle of darkening gray. Then we hear the staccato pitter-patter of RAIN DROPS. Ja looks up and they begin to hit his face. At first just a few, but then they come faster. Jamie tries to climb out again. But he slips back in. Another try and this time he almost makes it before sliding back down. Jamie's panic rises as he tries to claw out of the hole. it’s futile as his fingers cut through the mud like butte

Henry! HENRY!! The rain falls harder as the storm hits it’s stride. And hole is already starting to fill with water. Jamie’s eyes grow wild as he suddenly throws himself against the walls like a trapped animal.
As he limps back towards the hole with the ladder, he hea Jamie screaming.
Henry hustles back to the hole but Jamie is too frantic t notice.
Jamie!! Jamie, I’m here!!  Jamie snaps out of it as Henry lowers the ladder. Jamie scrambles up and promptly doubles over trying to quell th panic.
You alright?
I thought maybe you decided to leave me down there.
Why would I do that? Jamie glances up. Henry’s looking at him like he’s crazy. Jamie hauls up the ladder and moves off:
Come on. Let’s get this over with.

ON PAPPY MCALLAN (60'S), eyes closed, his expression tranquil. He is dressed as we will see him throughout, in his Sunday best. WIDEN TO REVEAL Jamie and Henry standing over him. Henry pulls a sheet over Pappy’s face then rega the ramshackle coffin made of mismatched scrap wood.
I wish to hell we’d been able to get to town. Jamie moves to Pappy’s feet and Henry to his head as they to putting the body in the coffin. As they lift:
Gently now.
Right, wouldn’t want to hurt him.
(sharp) That’s not the point.
Sorry, brother. I’m just tired. With ludicrous care they lower the corpse into the box. Henry reaches for the lid and starts to put it on:

Go on. I'll finish up here.  5. Jamie nods and throws a last look at the corpse. We STAY him as he drifts outside to the porch. A HAMMER STRIKING NAIL gives him pause. He produces an almost empty bottle bourbon from his back pocket. He downs it.

The rain and wind have slowed down. ON A PAIR OF BOOTS as they trudge through thick, ankle-deep mud. WIDEN TO REVEA that the boots belong to LAURA MCALLAN (Caucasian, 30's). She follows Jamie and Henry who carry the coffin. Laura i more plain than pretty and there’s a tired strength in he eyes. She stumbles in the muck and we hear her VOICE OVER

When I think of the farm I think of mud. Encrusting knees and hair. Marching in boot shaped patches across the floor. I dreamed in brown. The procession arrives at the grave. Henry and Jamie set coffin down and work ropes underneath it as Laura looks o The ropes slip, the coffin tumbles to the ground. Wood GROANS and there’s a loud CRACK from inside.
Dammit.
What if we stand at either end and run the ropes lengthwise?
Coffin’s too narrow. It falls again it could break open. Jamie shrugs, “so what?” HENRY (CONT’D) No. Laura reacts to a mule pulled wagon she sees approaching.

The Jacksons. As the wagon gets closer we see the JACKSONS: HAP and FLORENCE ride up front with their youngest RUEL (10). Beh them their children, MARLON (15) and LILLY MAY (12). Henr moves towards them:
Henry, don’t.
S’not my fault what happened.
Just let them go.

Leaving us in the middle of the season? Least they can do is lend a hand. Laura and Jamie trade a look as Henry waves the wagon dow Hap’s eyes are tight and cold as he clucks the horses to stop. Laura ventures a nod at Florence, Florence ignores
Can you help us out here? Hap considers Jamie. The cracked coffin sinking into the
Hap? Florence puts a hand on Hap’s hand. They look to each oth for an answer that isn’t there. Laura shifts her weight, looks away from Henry.
I was a thirty one year old virgin when I met Henry McAllan in the Spring of 1939.

ON LAURA, mud-free and squeaky clean. She is smiling coyl and we WIDEN TO REVEAL that she’s sitting across from Hen who is quiet and inscrutable throughout. The other guests the dinner table: Laura’s brother, TEDDY (late 20’s) and MOTHER and FATHER (50's). This place is a sharp contrast the farm. It’s light and pristine with clean napkins and crisp, white shirts. Laura’s V.O.:

I lived with my parents in the house I grew up in. My world was small and he was my rescuer from a life in the margins. Laura’s mother has sniffed out the sparks between Laura a Henry. Mom gives Henry the hard sell with a smile as Laur squirms in the spotlight.  LAURA’S MOTHER Oh, an engineering degree from Ole Miss? Laura’s a college graduate, got her teaching certificate from West Tennessee State.

Oh, my dear sister’s the smartest one in the family. Made better grades than I ever did. (winking to Henry) Never heard the end of it. LAURA’S MOTHER Laura, why don’t you play some piano after dinner. (to Henry re: Laura) You really must hear her sing. (to Laura) You should play something for Mr. McAllan later.
Momma. LAURA’S MOTHER How about that hymn y’all did at service last Sunday? Or Ave Maria, that’s beautiful.
Momma.
What?

I’m quite sure that Teddy did not bring his new boss, Mr. McAllan, over to hear hymns. LAURA’S MOTHER Well, let’s ask him then. Mr. McAllan, would you like to hear some music later? Eyes turn to Henry as he finishes a bite of food and wipe his mouth.
I like hymns. Laura, de-centered.
Laura opens the door to REVEAL Henry with a bouquet of flowers. She smiles, surprised.
I was unused to male admiration and knew only that I wanted more. It was at least a reprieve from the sincere pity and insincere kindness directed at old maids.
Laura and Henry gazing at the big screen. She steals a glance at him.
He didn’t feel the need to fill the air with words like I did. He had the self confidence I lacked. He was, after all, a veteran of the Great War.
Henry and Laura walk hand in hand. The dogwood trees are blooming and flurries of white petals flit on gentle bree Henry picks a petal out of Laura’s hair and they hold a l

Though he never spoke of it, his limp was a constant reminder of his brave sacrifice. I can’t say that I was truly in love with him, but I was so grateful to him it dwarfed everything else... Henry takes her face in his hands, grinds a kiss onto her mouth. Laura recovers, tries a smile, waits for some tenderness, a grand romantic declaration--
My brother, Jamie’s coming up from Oxford in a few weeks. I’d like for him to meet you.
Laura and Henry in the center of the BUZZING terminal. La is dressed for the occasion. Henry paces, excited. A LOUDSPEAKER announces the train’s arrival.
(checking his watch) Right on time. That’s rare for Jamie. Henry scans the crowd, smiles.
There. Henry points. Jamie strides through the crowd. He is fres clean, beautiful. Henry moves to him as fast as limp will permit. A warm, rocking hug. They step back and study eac other’s faces.
You look good, brother.
Likewise.
The air up here in Memphis agrees with you. (looking at Laura) Or is it something else? Jamie throws Laura a movie star smile. And she is immediately taken by his charm.
This is Miss Chappell. (to Laura) My brother, Jamie.
Pleased to meet you.
The pleasure is all mine. With exaggerated gallantry, Jamie takes Laura’s offered h and kisses it.
He thinks he’s a character in one of his plays.
Henry tells me you’re studying theater at Ole Miss.  10.
(forefinger in the air) Ah, but which play, dear brother? Hamlet? Faust? Prince Hal?
Hopefully one of them fellas can earn you a decent wage someday.
What do you think, Miss Chappell?
I think you’re more of a Puck. Jamie is impressed and the dazzle in his smile shows it.
Dear lady, thou speakest right. I am that merry wanderer of the night.
Who’s Puck?
(mock despair) Lord what fools these mortals be. Despite being older, Henry has always been in Jamie’s sha
Puck’s a kind of mischievous sprite.
A hobgoblin. Forgive me, I’m only trying to impress her.
Laura’s not the impressionable type.
Good for her. Jamie smiles and winks at Laura.

WELL-HEELED GUESTS lounging on Queen Anne couches. BLACK SERVANTS buzz about with trays. A BLACK BIG BAND plays something watered-down swing.  11. Laura, Henry and Jamie giggling in a lush nook. Jamie is story. Laura is rapt. Henry’s heard it.
Next thing I knew I was sucked under, concussed and bleeding, I was as good as gone. Another victim of the great flood of twenty- seven.
I can’t believe you never told me this. (to Jamie) Then what happened?

I saw a glimmering light. Like a fallen star. (wiggling his fingers) And a great big hand reached out of it. Thought it was God himself come to take me. But it wasn’t. It was my dear big brother, Henry.
(smiling to Henry) You saved his life. You’re a hero.
He is indeed.
What else was I supposed to do? Let him drown? It’s not a pleasant memory for Henry. As he shrugs it off SERVANT refreshes their champagne. HENRY (CONT’D) That’11 do--
We've barely had any. Don’t worry Henry, I’ve got more stamina than you-— Jamie tips the servant’s hands, extends the pour.
What, from modeling clothes? Don’t know how you do that. Seems so undignified for a man.  12.

We'll have plenty of time later for you to evaluate my life choices, brother. Tonight, we celebrate. (raising his glass) Here’s to the future. Whatever it may hold. May you be blessed with happiness, health, prosperity and... (to Henry re: Laura) ...-if she’ll have you, maybe even a house full of children. My love to you both. Said genuinely. Laura is touched. Despite himself, Henry too. They clink glasses and drink.
Ooh, bubbly. Just then the band switches the beat and ups volume. It’s time to dance. As couples start to move to the dance floo Jamie looks to Henry:
Would you mind terribly if I hada dance with your girl? (off Henry’s shrug) Miss Chappell? Care to take a spin? Laura looks to Henry, Henry nods.

Jamie and Laura whirl. Jamie’s got Fred Astaire moves. Bu this is new to Laura and she’s awkward. Jamie patiently leads and soon Laura's swept off her feet. For a while it feels like it’s just the two of them out there.

Jamie saw in a different way. When his eyes were on me, I felt like I was no longer invisible. Laura and Jamie lock eyes and the connection is overwhelm The envious eyes of other women in the room. Laura shrugs off Henry’s questioning gaze. The song ends. Laura is breathless.
Jamie escorts Laura back to the table. She’s flushed. Hen notices it.  13.
Excuse me. I’11 be back. Jamie moves off and Henry looks to Laura.
You look especially pretty tonight.
Thank you.
Jamie has that effect on girls. They sparkle for him. (beat) He likes you. I can tell.
I’m sure he doesn’t dislike anyone.

At least not anyone in a skirt. (re: the dance floor) See what I mean? Laura looks and sees Jamie on the dance floor with a PRET GIRL. The girl effortlessly follows Jamie through a serie of turns and dips. Laura suddenly feels foolish and tries cover it as she sips her champagne glass empty. Henry ref it.

Henry's marriage proposal didn’t play out like I'd pictured it would. He wasn’t kneeling and the question actually came out as more of a statement. Henry wasn’t a romantic. He was made of sturdier stuff. But he was a good, hard working man. And he loved me. And I knew that he would provide, be true, and give me children. And for that, I could certainly love him in return. Laura steals glances at Jamie dancing and smiling.
INT. HENRY/LAURA’S MEMPHIS HOUSE - DAY Henry carries Laura over the threshold.  14.
I loved domestic life. Then, in a MONTAGE we see Laura around the house cooking, ironing, cleaning and being domestic.

Yielding to Henry and waiting for him to come home to me was what I'd been put on earth to do. CUT TO: Laura holding INFANT AMANDA LEIGH as they finish dinner . Henry insists that she stay seated as he cleans up the dishes.
And when Amanda Leigh was born I became hers completely. Another CUT and Laura plays blocks on the floor with now ONE-YEAR-OLD AMANDA LEIGH while Henry tunes the radio.
But then came the day that changed everything. Forever... We PUSH IN on the radio as we hear Franklin Delano Roosev

Mister Vice President, Mister Speaker, members of the Senate and of the House of Representatives. Yesterday, December 7th, 1941, a date which will live in infamy, the United States of America was suddenly and deliberately attacked by naval and air forces of the Empire of Japan. EXT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - DAY

Daddy borrowed Mister Robert’s and ‘nems truck to take me. That’s what I remember most. The first things and the last things stick the hardest. A gathering of NEIGHBORS in the tidy yard. Ronsel in cris TRAVELING CLOTHES, his sister, Lilly May, hanging on his neck.
Don’t forget about us.  15.
You know I won’t. Marlon steps forward with a brave face, pumps his brother hand, claps his back. Little brother Ruel follows suit.
Take care Ron.
Y'all don’t be quarreling. Pitch in good, help Mama ‘nem.
We will.

And keep them no ‘count boys away from Lilly May. Don’t let her turn fast. Lilly May smiles through her sniffles, pops Ronsel on the shoulder as she steps back. Marlon does a little salute. looks on from the driver's seat of his rough-idling truck pride and doubt competing for his eyes. Ronsel slings his pack over his shoulder, ambles over to where Florence holds herself against the cab. She puts he hand on his forehead, cups his face, holds her hand over beating heart. Bomp. Bomp. Bomp. He’s alive. Ronsel holds Florence's hand over his heartbeat.
You just come back.
I will Mama.

You come all the way back. Ronsel kisses her hand. Florence pats his chest and peels herself away. Neighbors and family surge forward as Hap e the truck away, spill into the dirt road waving and whistling. But Florence doesn’t look back.
I can’t look back. I didn’t look back. It’s bad luck to watch somebody leave.  16.
Florence opening the windows, chasing out dust. Exorcisin fear from the corners of the cabin with her broom.

I held his heartbeat in my hand. I remember every beat. He was warm and alive. I know every place in him. Florence throws open the back door. Beyond a small green garden, COTTON FIELDS stretch infinitely from her yard po Hap and Marlon are slow-moving specks on the horizon. Florence raises her hand in a wave.
And it was all I could do to not look back. One of the specks waves back.

No, I don’t have favorites. INT. HAP’S CHURCH - DAY Hap in the pulpit, sweating and quaking and exalting. Swa trees visible through the missing boards behind him. A br blowing in through an empty window pane. Florence in the front row, flanked by her children, duly listening. Her e closed.
I love them all equally. Every mother does. But during all those four years, all that time he was gone... Florence’s eyes open.
I only prayed for him. Hap catches Florence’s eye, shoots her a smile.
God'1l forgive me.
John 14:1-3 “In my Father’s house, are many mansions. (MORE )
Hap, head words. Hap lifts the crowd, The words 16A.

If it were not so I would have told you. I go to prepare a place for you... that’s where I am, ye may be also.” (beat) I know that brings me comfort. It brings me comfort that One Morning My getting up is gonna be just a little bit easier than the day before. One Morning My children are not gonna wake up in this place, they’re gonna open they eyes on a new sky. One Morning We gonna knock the boot from off our neck, we gonna shake the chains from round our feet. Oh Yes One morning! And I’m not talking about the hereafter. I’m talking about the Right Now! Oh One Morning! I said One morning Soon... (song) hung low, is silent. Speechless, searching for
That’s all right, sir. Take your time! his heartbroken eyes to the congregation. He scans looking for a reason. His eyes catch on Florence. still don’t come.
Church. ..Beloved. I don’t know I just don’t know. (beat) You see how they done him? Y'all seen how they done him. Father I Stretch My Hand To Thee
The shadow of a biplane crop duster BUZZES across fields.
The army made Jamie a bomber pilot. But it’s my fault he’s up there.
INT. HENRY’S CAR (MOVING) - DAY - SIMULATANEOUS Henry drives on the road adjacent to the cotton field. As the plane roars past his VOICE OVER continues:

When Jamie was a boy he had questions about my time in the Great War. How many Huns did I kill? How had I been injured? Why did they call it great? And all I could do was make him promise that if he ever had to be a soldier he would get up to the sky. They say battle is cleaner in the sky.

Henry, Laura, 2 YEAR OLD AMANDA LEIGH, and INFANT ISABELL finish breakfast. Henry kisses all his girls good-bye. He rolls a sheath of BLUEPRINTS, stuffs them in a tube stamp ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS. Grabs a construction helmet.

A pair of TODDLERS ride the long tail their MOTHER’S COTT SACK. The mother picks and steps, picks and steps in automated drudgery. SHIFF SHIFF SHIFF. The babies gliding backwards on their mother’s effort. Other PICKERS in wear synchrony in the rows alongside her.

Work kept me from my family. But the army needed bases and airfields and I was happy to oblige. My great- great grand daddy and his slaves built the farm I grew up on.  18. Henry leans next to his idling car, a worn NO TRESPASSING sign hangs limp from a tree. Henry eyes a string of dista SHARECROPPERS. He reaches down and grabs a handful of ear

One time Grandaddy told me to go grab up a handful of dirt from the yard, and I did. He asks me “What are you holding?" I said “Dirt”. He says “that's right now give it to me." So I do and he says “Now what's this I've got in my hand?" “Dirt” , I says. Then he says “Naw boy, this is LAND I've got. Do you know why?" Henry sniffs the dirt in his hands, tastes it, spits it o
And he says “because I OWN it. It's mine. And one day it'll be yours. But in the meantime, to you and every other person who doesn't own it, it’s just dirt.” Henry tosses the dirt away.

Sunlight beams through stained glass and a preacher resid over a small congregation. Henry, Laura, Amanda Leigh (4) and Isabelle (2), walk down the aisle followed by Pappy. HENRY’S MOTHER lies in repose. Laura moves past the caske quickly with the children in tow.

Except that land never became mine. Pappy sold it after the flood. He told people that the river wiped him out. But that was a lie. Pappy stops and takes a long look down at the body. Henry lays a flower in the casket. Pappy sobs heavily as he wri the hat he holds in his hands. Henry starts to reach for father’s shoulder, hesitates, clasps his hands behind him instead.
He walked away from that land gladly. Another PARISHIONER drapes a comforting arm around Pappy.  19.
And when mama died, he sold my dreams as payment for his grief.
Where Henry and Laura make love. Henry climaxes, then slo rolls off of her. They both catch their breath and stare the ceiling for several post-coital beats, then:
Honey, by the way. I bought a farm in Mississippi. Laura’s head snaps towards him, her face smeared with sho But Henry continues like it’s great news:
It’s 40 miles south of Greenville near a town called Marietta. We’ll be moving in three weeks time.
When did you do this?
Just recently. I rented us a house in town. It’s a gorgeous with a big old porch, an oak tree, four bedrooms. You and the girls will love it.
But we love this house.
They each get their own room and Pappy can have his own space.
Pappy?

Of course. Now that momma’s gone someone's got to look after him. (then) Wait ‘til you see it. It’s gota modern electric stove. And it’s only 3 blocks from the elementary school. And it’s only about a half hour drive out to the farm. (MORE )
Bought it from a couple who lost their son in the war. Felt bad taking it at such a low price, but they wanted out. (then) I'll have Pappy drive the truck up next week.
What truck?

The pick up I bought to use on the farm. Got a tractor too. John Deere Model B. Helluva machine. I’ll be able to farm a hundred acres by myself. Imagine that. Henry realizes Laura has been looking at him, agape.
You're mighty quiet.
I'm mighty surprised.
But you knew I always intended to have my own farm someday. I’m sure I mentioned it.
No, Henry. I had no idea. I would’ve remembered that.
Well. I’m telling you now. We've got ourselves two hundred acres of fertile land. And with that tractor I don’t need a bunch of sharecroppers, I can do most of the work myself.
What about my family?
Me and the girls are your family.
I mean my mother and father.
They can visit. You can too.  21.
But...three weeks?

Laura, honey, in a year’s time I'll turn enough profit to buy us another hundred acres. Man up the road is itching to sell. Lot better living than I’m making now. (then) You're going to love it. I know you will. You’ll see.
We find the McAllan convoy leaving town. Laura drives the DeSoto sedan with Isabelle and Amanda Leigh. Henry and Pa are in a pick-up truck packed full of belongings includin Laura’s piano.
As the two-car McAllan convoy rolls by. It’s much more ru out here and a world away from Memphis.

It’s even more charming than Henry described. The process unfolds from the caravan. Henry watches Laura as she takes it in. She looks at Henr and softens, the house is lovely. He moves to her and tak her hand as they walk towards their new home.
Mommy flowers!
I see, honey. (to Henry) You didn’t tell me we had azaleas.
So we do. Isabelle coughs as she curls deeper into mommy.
She's done in. Let’s get inside.
Key should be under the mat.  22. Just then the the front door opens to REVEAL a big, bear man, ORRIS STOKES (Caucasian, 30's). He’s not friendly.
Who the hell are you?
We’re the McAllans. The new tenants of this house. Who are you?
Orris Stokes. The new owner of this house.
I rented this place from George Suddeth just three weeks ago.
Suddeth sold me the house last week. And he didn’t say nothing ‘bout no renters.
Is that a fact? I guess I need to refresh his memory.
He left town three days ago.
I gave him a hundred dollar deposit.
You get anything in writing?
We shook on the deal. Pappy spits on the ground, shakes his head in disgust.
I paid him a hundred dollars cash right there in the living room. I had dinner with him and his wife.
You best be getting on. Orris shuts the door behind him.  23.
You got swindled, boy. Damn fool. Henry is crestfallen. Another cough from Isabelle. Off th whole group looking to Henry.
Then we’ll have to stay on the farm. There’s a house. We can make it work.
You mean out there with the niggers and the farm hands?
It’s the only place big enough for all of us. There’s nothing else in town. Believe me, I looked.

The McAllan’s two-car convoy rocks and bumps their way do the road. The land is flat and mostly featureless. Africa American men, women and children dot the fields, tilling earth with mule drawn plows. Eventually they pass run down sharecropper’s shacks with yards. African American women hang clothes on lines as children play or watch the procession from porches.
Hap surveys his land. Ruel and Marlon toil shoulder to shoulder in the fading light. Florence and Lily May chip at the day’s chores.

What good is a deed? My grandfathers and great-uncles, grandmothers and grand-aunts, father and mother--broke, tilled, toiled, planted, plucked, razed, burned, broke again. Worked this land all their lives. This land that would never be theirs. They worked until they sweated. They sweated until they bled. They bled until they died. Died with the dirt of this same 200 acres underneath they fingernails. Died, clawing at the hard brown back that would never be theirs. All they deeds undone. (MORE )

(beat) Yet this man, this place, this law, say you need a deed. All the blood and sweat and dying with dirt under your fingernails don’t count. Doesn’t make it yours. Say you need a deed, not Deeds. So what good is a deed? A deed is a piece of paper. One of my great-uncles, Uncle William, got ahold of a piece of land during reconstruction. A good piece of land right next to the river. He had a deed. Had his piece of paper and all. Four white men rode up on horses one day, aimed they pistols, said it was theirs. My uncle’s good deed torn into forty pieces and thrown to the wind. It was too good, you see? The land he had claimed. And so I ask: what good is a deed?
The bridge spans a small river. As the two-car convoy dri over the creaky structure Henry leans his head out the wi and shouts back to Laura in the DeSoto.
This is it! We’re on our land now!
Pride goeth before destruction and a haughty spirit before a fall. Hap leads his MULE into the stall, gives its mane a good before tying a feed bag on.  24.

That mule made me a share tenant, not a share cropper. And it had me dreaming about having my own piece of land. Maybe that’s where the problem started. Hap saunters back to his cabin, luxuriates in the calm of completed day’s work. INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - SUNSET Hap and his family shoulder to shoulder around an overflo dinner table. Cabbage and onions from Florence’s garden. cast iron skillet with rabbit in heavy brown gravy. A pla of sliced tomatoes goes around. A SURVEYOR’S MAP with outlined parcels is pinned to the wall. A pencil on a str hangs from a nail next to it. Hap stares at it as he eats Hap leaps up, napkin still tucked around his neck to redr boundary, scribble notes.
If only fences could be put up with lead.
The get taken down with lead all the time. Hap winks at Florence, Florence blushes.
Won’t be too much longer, Papa will it? This time next year I’ma have about fifty acres of cotton, fifty acres of oats, fifty acres of rice--
Fool, rice don’t grow here.
Never call your brother a fool.
Well I’ma grow it anyway.
That’s why I’m not gon’ be no farmer, I’ma be a stenographer.
A ste- what?  25.
It’s kinda like a typist.
They don’t allow no colored typists.
Your sister will be the first.
And? You'll be buying all your food from us. We gon’ get all your typist money.
Nuh -unh. ‘Cause I’ma be in California or Chi-cago where all the good jobs at.
War gonna be over by then.
No it won’t-- Sudden silence settles over the group. LILLY MAY (CONT’D) I mean...but Ronsel, he--he’1l probably be home Mama.

I never realized how much I needed that until he turned away from me. INT. A MODEST GERMAN HOUSE - BEDROOM — DAY Sunlight fills the room where Ronsel and Resl sleep peacefully entwined. We notice a delicate gold necklace w a_crucifix hanging from Resl’s neck. A few quiet beats, t a cacophony of HORN HONKS and JEEP ENGINES crescendos. Ronsel wakes quickly but Resl snoozes on. Then, outside, hears HOOTS and HOLLERS.
Ronsel extracts himself from Resl’s sleepy embrace and mo to the window. There he sees a procession of American soldiers hanging off jeeps and trucks, waving American fl

War's over! Hitler’s dead! The war’s over! Ronsel watches them wondering if it’s true. Resl joins hi at the window as the impromptu victory parade rolls by.  54. They look at each other, both knowing what it means: he’s going home soon. A melancholy embrace. Ronsel closes his eyes.
INT. BUS —- DAY As Ronsel is suddenly woken up by the CONDUCTOR (White, 4 who moves down the aisle from the loose White section to over-packed Colored section.
Tupelo! Next stop! Tupelo! Ronsel is in his dress uniform, adorned with medals. He shakes off his sleep, looks out the window.

Home again, home again. Jiggety - jig. Coon, spade, darky, nigger. Went off to fight for my country and came back to find it hadn’t changed a bit. Ronsel reaches into his pocket and pulls out Resl’s gold necklace and crucifix - a keepsake. Ronsel notices a LITT BOY staring at him. Ronsel winks. The Little Boy salutes. Ronsel returns the salute.
EXT. TRICKLEBANK’S GENERAL STORE - DAY Ronsel hops off the bus, pack slung, medals twinkling. He takes his time surveying the stark town strip, a few loitering WHITE TOWNSMEN eye him as he passes.

INT. TRICKLEBANK’S GENERAL STORE - CONTINUOUS Ronsel enters and finds Laura chatting with store owner, TRICKLEBANK (Caucasian, female, 30's). Rose is back-count tough and wears a bandana to pull back her hair.
Howdy, Miz Tricklebank.
Ronsel, is that you?  54a.
Yes, ma’am, last time I looked.  55.
Well, I declare. Aren’t you grown up. How are you?
Can’t complain. How you been?
Getting along fine. You seen your folks yet? As Ronsel grabs canned goods, sugar, and candy:
No, I just got in. I wanted to stop and buy a few things for ‘em first.
Hello, Ronsel. I’m Mrs. McAllan. Your parents work on our farm.
How do, ma’am?
Do Hap and Florence know you’re coming home?
No, I wanted to surprise ‘em.
Your mother talks about you all the time. I know they’1l be mighty glad to see you.
Likewise.
(re: Ronsel’s purchases) That everything?
Yes, ma’am.
Sugar and candy too?
Sugar’s for my momma. Candy’s for Marlon and Lilly May. Figured I'd spoil ‘ema little. (MORE )
(smiling re: his stripes) Sergeant’s pay.
I’m sure they'll appreciate that.
My brother served in the Pacific. And my husband’s brother was a bomber pilot. Both of them fine, thank God. Nice to see you boys finally coming home.
Comes to four dollars even. As Rose puts Ronsel’s things into a sack, Orris Stokes en the store. He’s so big he takes up the entire doorway.
Well looky what we got here. A jig in a uniform. Ronsel ignores the comment and pays Rose:
Thank you, Miz Tricklebank.
Sure thing. Just then Henry and Pappy enter the store with ANOTHER MA Ronsel grabs his things and tries to step around Stokes s can exit. But Stokes moves in front of him.
Where you think you’re going, boy?
Beg pardon, suh. Just trying to get home to see my folks.
Not that way you ain’t.
Henry, this is Hap and Florence's son, Ronsel. He just returned from overseas.
Well, that explains why you’re trying to leave by the front door. (MORE )
You must be confused as to your whereabouts.
I ain’t confused at all, suh.
Oh, I think you are, boy. I don’t know what they let you do over there, but you’re in Mississippi now, nigger. You use the back door.

Go on now. We don’t want any trouble. Go on. Fists clench as the air thickens with hostility. Ronsel i anchored where he stands, head high and defiant as he squarely meets the gaze of each man in the room. Laura's eyes plead with him to just go. Then Ronsel looks to Papp

You know, suh, you’re right. We didn’t go in the back over there. General Patton put us right up on the front lines. Yessuh, he took us when nobody else thought we were worth a damn. And you know we did? We kicked the hell outta Hitler and them Jerries. All while every one of you was back here safe and sound at home. No need to thank me. (then) Miz Tricklebank. Miz McAllan. The white men are agape as Ronsel grabs his things and strides out the back door. Angles toward the long dusty r out of town. INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - NIGHT

Bless us, oh Lord, and these thy gifts which we are about to receive from thy bounty through Christ our Lord and savior. Hap, Florence, Marlon, Ruel and Lilly May, all with their eyes closed, mid-prayer:  58.
And, Lord, thank you for the sun you been sending to make the cotton grow and for the health of all here present. And, Lord Jesus, please watch over my boy, Ronsel, wherever in creation he may be.
Amen. Heads snap to the doorway where Ronsel is standing. The Jacksons are collectively frozen.
Well, ain’t nobody gonna offer me some supper?
Ronsel! And Lilly May is up like a flash and in Ronsel’s arms. Florence is immediately driven to tears as she wraps her around Ronsel and covers him with kisses.
My baby...
Hi, momma.
So grown.
Handsome too. Marlon works his way in and hugs Ronsel tightly.
Marlon here’s catching up with me! How tall are you?
Wha’d you get all them medals for?
How was the trip home?
You get ‘em for killing Why didn’t you write to tell Germans? us you was coming?  59.
Quit fussing over him now and let him say hello to his father. They part so Hap can take a look at Ronsel. Then Ronsel rushes up and hugs him. Hap holds his son, tears welling.

I knew you’d come. I prayed for it. EXT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - NIGHT It’s a warm night and a blanket of stars covers the sky. Cigarette smoke curls up into it and we find Ronsel on th porch of the shack, smoking as he stares at the heavens. reacts when Hap and Florence come out.
I’ve never known you to smoke, son.
A lot’s changed.
You sure you get enough to eat?
I’m stuffed. Used to dream about them biscuits, Momma.
I dreamt about you too.
What did you see? Florence shakes her head and shivers at the thought. Then
You back with us now. Safe and sound.
Be nice to have another pair of hands. With you home we might can make up what we lost after my accident. Payoff the lien, get a new contract, go back to being tenants next year--
Maybe he got plans of his own, Hap. Let him find his own mind.  60.

Oh, no. Yeah. I mean, of course. I'll stay awhile. It’1ll give me time to figure things out. Put the war behind me. Hap is excited by the prospect, leans against the post hi crutches forgotten. But Ronsel is far away and is only feigning enthusiasm. HEADLIGHTS of a truck coming down th road. The truck pulls into the yard and Henry gets out.
What’s he want now? Ronsel stiffens. Hap and Florence trade a look as Henry strides up to the porch.
Evening, Hap. Florence.
Mist McAllan. This is our son, Ronsel, I told you about.
We've met. (then) I’d better speak to you alone, Hap.
I ain’t a child. Sir. You got something to say to my father, you can say it to me too.
All right then. You’re asking for a heap of trouble by acting like you did earlier at Tricklebank’s. And I know you don’t want trouble, least of all for your family here.
What’d you do? He couldn’ta done anything.
Just tried to walk out the door is all.
The front door. And when my father corrected him he made a fine speech. Put us all in our place, didn’t you?
Is that true? (off Ronsel’s nod) Then I reckon you best apologize. Henry waits and Ronsel glares. But Ronsel knows he has no choice and he forces the words out:
I’m mighty sorry, Mr. McAllan.
My father’1l wanna hear it too.
Ronsel will pay him a visit after church tomorrow. Won’t you, son?
Yes. Hap needles Ronsel out the side of his eye.
Sir.
Good. We'll be expecting you, boy. Henry strolls back to his truck and pulls off. Hap sees t frustration in Ronsel’s eyes.
No point in fighting ‘em. They just gon’ win every time.

Not used to walking away from fights, daddy. Not anymore. Ronsel eases past his father. Florence catches Ronsel’s h at the door, squeezes. Ronsel kisses his mother’s hand, p it as he moves off. Hap and Florence exchange wordless worries in the dark.
Ronsel & Florence lounge in their separate thoughts. Take the sleeping silence. Ronsel materializes a Hershey Bar a lays it on her knee.
For you.  61A. Florence stunned from her day dream.
Oh. I -- no. This is so much. Your brothers and sister will love this. I'll save it -- Florence moves to take the bar in her apron. Ronsel puts hands on hers.
No. It's for you.
Oh baby, I can't.
Go head. I'ma watch you. Florence giggles, backs in pampering. She ventures one mo square, pleasure washes over her face. Florence holds Ronsel's gaze stuffs down overflowing emotions.
(Beat) Thank you.
I love you Ma.
Shouting from the barn. It’s Henry arguing with Carl Atwo Their discussion moves towards the porch:  62.
I don’t give a damn! If you can’t do your job, I can’t keep you on. That’s how it works.
Henry, please, I got Vera and the girls and one on the way -- we don’t got anyplace else to go.
That’s not my problem, Carl. And I got kids too. But I’m runnin’ a farm here, not a charity.
Please, sir.
I'll give you to the end of the week. And then I want you gone. Henry walks away. As he moves past Laura and into the hou Carl stands there, shell-shocked. Then eventually, he mov off down the road.
Laura reading in a chair, rocking herself unconsciously. Atwood waddling up the porch steps--pregnant belly, fresh black eye and split lip.
Howdy Miz McAllan! Vera like a child, pressed against the screen door. Laura lowers her book, affixes pleasantness to her face.
Hello. Miss--
Vera. You can call me Vera.
Hello Vera.
This here is my youngest, Alma. Vera’s skinny daughter ALMA, recessive of chin and dull o eye lifts her gaze to Laura’s.  63.
We needa talk to you.
Vera crossing her dirty bare feet on Laura’s rug. Laura t not to notice. Her daughter Alma in the window picking at ends of her hair.
You cain’t put us off.
Excuse me?
We ain’t got nowhere to go if you put us off. Nobody’1l hire us this late in the season.
It’s not up to me Vera, it’s up to my husband. Vera rubs her pregnant belly.
I’m asking you to keep us on.
I’m telling you, it’s not my decision.
And if it was?
Laura hums as she churns butter on the porch while Henry reads the paper and Pappy smokes. Laura’s churning is especially tense and Henry notices:
Alright then, what is it?
What?
You got something on your mind. I can tell. (off Laura) You sing when you're happy. (MORE )
And hum when you’re not. C’mon now, out with it.
Vera Atwood is eight and a half months pregnant. Where would they go? How would they survive?
Ain’t this touching? Saint Laura, protector of women and children.
Atwood is a lazy, stupid drunk. He’s lucky I’ve kept him this long.
Then make him work on half shares like Hap and his family.
Why would I go through all that when I can just hire a new tenant?
Because you are a Christian.
The Lord ain’t the one putting food on our table.
Didn’t you tell me most farmers around here can’t find enough help to make a crop? (beat) Call it a business decision. For the good of the farm. Laura has a point.
I’ll have a word with Carl tomorrow morning. Just a word. Laura rewards him with the tiniest smile, softens her churning. Henry basks in her quiet favor.

Next she'll be telling you what to plant.  65. EXT. MCALLAN FARM HOUSE -— MORNING Laura’s hands red, raw, and forgotten between her knees. washboard leans in a still steaming bucket of gray water. Laura stares at a dead mouse curled on the bottom step.

Violence is part and parcel of country life. You're forever being assailed by dead things. Amanda Leigh accidentally bumps a pair of trousers off th clothesline. Amanda Leigh jumps back from the muddy heap, braces for her mother’s censure. Laura just blinks. Amand Leigh slings the pants back onto the line and scurries aw
Dead mice, dead rabbits, dead possums, dead birds.
A POSSUM CORPSE languishes beneath a tree. Ants march in out of its pink mouth.

You find them in the yard. You smell them rotting under the house. EXT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - DAY A sharp flick of the wrist, Florence SNAPS a chicken’s ne The body flops and unspirals itself as she runs a boning knife across the jugular, spills hot blood onto the dirt.
And then there are the creatures you kill for food.
Dirty CHILDREN straddle and climb the rickety porch raili Vera Atwood nudges tight brown fur backward over limp squirrel haunches.
Chickens, hogs, deer, frogs, squirrels. Pluck, skin, disembowel, debone, fry. Vera wipes her nose on her shoulder, wedges the too-dull pocketknife deeper under the skin.  66.
Eat. Start again. Kill. Laura runs a pipe cleaner down the barrel of a HUNTING RI
I learned how to stitch up a bleeding wound, load and fire a shotgun, reach into the womb of heaving sow to deliver a breech piglet. My hands did these things. Laura snaps the barrel into place.
But I was never easy in my mind.
Laura gnawing at the balls of her hands. Thick yellow callouses peel off between her teeth. She chews them thoughtfully. Stares out the window entranced.

Momma, somebody’s coming! A handsome soldier in aviator sunglasses carrying a suitc Laura looks and realizes: AMANDA LEIGH (CONT’D) Uncle Jamie!! Laura shoots to her feet, smooths her hands against her apron.

Jamie?! Henry whoops and bolts off the porch, limp and all. Laura hangs back in the doorway. She straightens her dress and runs her fingers through her hair. She sights her dirty fingernails, clasps her hands behind her back. Henry rocks Jamie in a tight embrace. They separate, look each other. Grab each other again.
You look good, brother.
You look like hell.
Don’t sugarcoat it now. 67. Laura edges closer with Amanda Leigh and Isabelle, she ho out her hands for a squeeze. Jamie smiles, scoops her int hug instead.
Laura. Sweet sister-in-law.
Welcome home, Jamie.
How are you liking it here in Henry’s version of paradise? Laura starts to answer but is spared from having to lie b
You’d think a son would see fit to greet his own father.
Dearest Pappy. I’d forgotten how much I missed you. Said with a cut of sarcasm as Jamie shakes Pappy’s hand.
(to Jamie re: Pappy) He’s missed you too. He won't admit it but he has.
I bet. And he probably quit smoking and joined the NAACP too. Laura laughs and Jamie winks at her. Pappy doesn’t apprec the joke. Then Jamie smiles at Amanda Leigh and Isabelle.
Well hello little ones. Give your uncle Jamie a hug. The girls run and jump into his arms.
The jitter of Jamie’s hand as he cradles a lit cigarette. pours a drink and finishes in a single draught. Pappy tak note, doesn’t hide his disdain. Henry pretends not to see  68.
So what's it like being a big hero?
I wouldn’t know.
Don’t give me that. Army wrote me about your fancy medals. Said they was the highest honors an airman could receive.
I was lucky. Lotta guys weren't.
Bet you got plenty of tail out of it too.
Jamie’s never needed medals to get girls.

Damn right. Takes after me that way. Your momma was the prettiest girl in Greenville. And I had ‘em all sniffing after me. Pappy smiles with his yellow teeth. Jamie shifts in his chair and lights one cigarette with another.
One thing’s for sure. You must’a killed a whole lotta Krauts to get all them medals. (beat) Well, how many’d you take out?
I don’t know.
Take a guess.
I don’t know. Why’s it matter?
A man ought to know how many men he’s killed.  69. Henry returns with the bottle and a glass. Jamie quickly uncorks it and pours heavily. He gulps it down and refill Henry is surprised.
I can tell you this. (beat) It was more than one.
(under his breath) Aw, shit. Pappy’s eyes narrow and he seethes for a beat,

Well, at least I looked my one in the eye before I shot him. Not like dropping bombs from a mile up in the air. Jamie throws back his drink and pours another. uncomfortable silence until Henry interrupts:
Well, good time to hit the hay. Got an early day tomorrow.

I'll just finish my drink. then smirks: Then there is Pappy absorbs this, grabs a lantern and shuffles out. Jam slugs back his whiskey. His eyes flick back to the bottle Henry grabs it and moves it out of range.
What you need is a good night’s sleep. Laura made a bed up for you. Jamie stands and Henry gives him a hug.
Welcome home, little brother. (beat) Now, go on, get some sleep. Henry starts to move off.
Actually it was more like four.
What?  70.
Miles up in the air. The altitude we dropped bombs from.
How can you even see anything from that high up?

You'd be surprised. Roads, cities, factories. Just not people. From twenty thousand feet they’re not even ants. (beat) Pappy’s right. A man ought to know. Jamie is haunted. Henry is concerned. INT. TRICKLEBANK’'S GENERAL STORE - DAY Rose Tricklebank takes her time bagging groceries for Jam Jamie is polite, but curt as his eyes are on his freshly purchased bottle of bourbon.
How long you been back from overseas now?
Coupl’a weeks.
And how’re you liking Marietta?
Lovely little town. Just lovely. Tricklebank moves to bag the bourbon, but Jamie intervene
Oh, I got that one. Let’s just put that right here. Jamie puts the bottle in a convenient spot, hurriedly sho in the remaining provisions.
There we go. Much obliged, Miz Tricklebank. You have yourself a wonderful day. Jamie smiles, grabs his stuff and heads out.  71.

Take care, now. Come back soon. EXT. TRICKLEBANK’S GENERAL STORE - DAY - CONTINUOUS Jamie hustles past a handful of WHITE TOWNSMEN on the por of the store. Among them is Orris Stokes. A passing car BACKFIRES. Jamie hits the ground and covers his head. Groceries spill everywhere. The townsmen murmur and stare
It’s alright. It was just a car. A helping hand extended, Jamie follows it up to Ronsel.

Backfired. Must have a stuck intake valve. Jamie looks up at the porch and sees mean eyes staring fr underneath hat brims. He ignores Ronsel’s hand, gets up a retrieves his groceries. Ronsel helps. But when Jamie gra the bourbon his hand shakes so badly he drops it. Thankfu it doesn’t break.
Dammit.
They say it stops eventually. Ronsel holds out his own hand and it shakes like Jamie's. They trade a look and despite being from different worlds there’s an instant kinship.
You’re Ronsel, Hap’s boy. (off Ronsel’s nod) Jamie McAllan. Henry’s brother. Jamie offers a hand shake. Ronsel is surprised by the sho of respect, but he obliges.
You walk here?
Yessir.
I‘1l give you a lift. (off Ronsel’s reluctance) C'mon.  72.
Thank you. Jamie and Ronsel move to the truck where Ronsel hops in t truck bed and Jamie hops in the driver’s side. Both of th are aware of the men still watching from the porch.

Jamie steals looks at Ronsel through the back window, squ with guilt. Memories of the B25 echo in his ears. Ronsel oblivious to it, chasing his daydreams flitting across th landscape. Jamie pulls over.
Come on up front.
I’m doing just fine back here.
Get in soldier! That’s an order! A beat, then the truck rocks as Ronsel hops off and gets the passenger side.
How do you know you outranked me?
I was a captain.
We had Negro captains. I served under plenty.
(shrugging) You obeyed my order. Bet you were a sergeant.
761st tank battalion. “Come Out Fighting”! Spearheaded for Patton. You?
I flew B-25's. Jamie reaches into the grocery bag between them and takes the bourbon bottle. He uncorks it then takes a long, much needed swig and drives on.  73.
So, sergeant, how do you like being back here in the Delta? Ronsel doesn’t answer, he just looks away.
Yeah, me too. (beat) Heard you and my Pappy had words.
(stiffening) I apologized for that. Then to Ronsel’s surprise, Jamie toasts with the bottle.
He’s a disagreeable sonovabitch. I’m sure he had it coming. (offering the bourbon) Here’s to you.
No thanks.
You always this stubborn? Or is it just around white people trying to be nice? Ronsel eyes Jamie, then he grabs the bottle, takes a quic sip and tries to hand it back.
What kind of NCO are you? Then Ronsel takes a big swig. So big it makes him choke a spill a little. Jamie laughs:
Don’t waste it now. That’s my medicine. I need every drop. Ronsel admits a slight grin as he recovers and hands the bottle back. Jamie takes a pull, then:
Hey, you tanker boys ever piss in your helmets?
Plenty of times.  74.
We had relief tubes up in the cockpit but sometimes it was easier just to use our flak helmets. And at twenty thousand feet? That piss freezes solid in less than minute.
It’s that cold up there?

I’m talking twenty, thirty below zero. And one time we were on this long haul and I went in my helmet and forgot all about it. Then when we got close to the target, I put the helmet back on. And we're doing our bombing run, dodging enemy flak and suddenly I feel something running down my face. They both laugh as Jamie passes the bottle back to Ronsel
I smelled like a damn latrine.
You must’a caught hell back at the officer's club.
My buddies never let me hear the end of it. (beat) The ones that made it back anyway.
Yeah. Lost some friends myself. They drive on in silence. INT. HENRY’S PICK-UP TRUCK - LATER Jamie and Ronsel pull up and stop at the Jackson's shack.
Thanks for the ride.
You’re welcome.  75. EXT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN —- DAY - SIMULATANEOUS Hap, having heard truck, comes out of the shack. Jamie ro the window down and smiles drunkenly.
Everything alright Mist Jamie?
Everything's fine. I just gave Ronsel here a lift from town. Ronsel rounds the truck, makes his way up the porch stair
I'll be heading into town again next Saturday afternoon. I’11 stop by, see if you want a ride.
That'd be fine.
(a nod) Hap. Then Jamie pulls out and weaves off down the road. Off Ha worried, as he looks at Ronsel...
