text: Laura sloshes through ankle deep mud, trudges to the lean outhouse. Laura opens the door to the BUZZING of flies. It’s a hot and the smell in here is oppressive. Breathing though her mouth, she lifts her skirt, squats and pees. She looks do at the mud caked onto her boots and the hem of her dress. SERIES OF SHOTS: LAURA’S TORTUOUS BATHING RITUAL
Saturday was my favorite day of the week. --LAURA pumping water in the yard, she hauls sloshing buc to the stove

It was the only day I felt truly clean. --LAURA hauling steaming water to a ZINC TUB in the yard, bathes her muddy DAUGHTERS. The water turns brown.  76. --The girls clean-washed and napping on the porch. LAURA lowers herself into their cloudy lukewarm leftovers. Laur cups water over herself, squats in the fleeting privacy o flapping sheet. PAPPY happens by, averts his eyes a littl too slowly.
The rest of the time, we stank. --Laura dumps the dirty water. Henry pecks her on the che as he drags into the yard covered in mud.
Where Laura looks at her expanding belly in a mirror. She turns profile and sighs with a grin. A beat, then Henry enters. Laura looks at him and smiles.
What? (off Laura) What is it?
I’m pregnant.
Oh Lord, honey... Oh Lord! (hugging and kissing her) Woo!
Shhh, you’1l wake the girls. Henry hugs her again and they are overjoyed.
Laura, with bleary eyes and a baby bump, shuffles into th room where Florence works in the kitchen.
What time is it?
Near to ten o’clock, Ms. Laura.
Good heavens.  77.
Yes'm, you definitely carrying a boy. Ronsel and Marlon both, couldn’t wake me for nothing. (beat) Something for you on the table. Laura notices a pretty bunch of lavender wrapped up in a bouquet.
Where are these from? Then Laura notices a note next to the flowers. “Congratulations. Love, Jamie” Laura closes her eyes and draws in the scent of the flowers.
He remembered I like lavender. How sweet. Then suddenly, she has to pee like a pregnant lady.
Ooh, excuse me. Nature calls.

As Laura hustles to the privy. Then she enters to find bouquets of lavender everywhere - in cans on the floor, i bunches nailed to the wall and hanging from the ceiling. Laura chuckles and smiles wide then takes a whiff. Not ba it’s working. Then she lifts her skirt, squats and pees.
Jamie and Ronsel stumble from the truck to the dilapidate saw mill. Ronsel hesitates.
C'mon, now, we’re clear of town, nobody’s out here. (with a bourbon bottle) Don’t make me drink alone. I will if I have to. Ronsel prys at a loose board.
Hope this damn thing don’t fall down on us.  78.
Jamie and Ronsel shimmy in through a ragged gap. It’s old decrepit and laden with cobwebs. Shafts of sunlight jut i through the wooden slats.
Used to come here when I was a boy. Whenever I needed to be alone and think.
Well I love what you’ve done with the place. Jamie offers Ronsel a smoke. Ronsel accepts and Jamie lig his own then tosses Ronsel the lighter. Ronsel lights up tosses the lighter back.
Why you treating me so nice?
Because you look like you could use it.
Bullshit. Jamie drags on his smoke and measures Ronsel with a drunk eye. Then:
We were somewhere over Austria and we made contact with a swarm of Messerschmitts. They were everywhere.

It’s bumpy as Jamie holds the plane on course. Suddenly bullets rip through the cockpit and the co-pilot gets shredded. Blood splatters on Jamie and on the “LADY LUCK” pin-up girl. Jamie is horrified and we hear his VOICE OVE
Took out my tail gunner, side gunner...my co-pilot. Made a deal with God right there. (MORE )
Swore if he saved me I was gonna do something right. I didn’t know what, but I promised anyway.
Next thing you know, whole bunch of P-38's show up. Just like the goddamn cavalry. They knocked those Germans right outta the sky. I swear they were angels sent by the Lord himself.
Jamie holds the plane on it’s shaky course. Then he looks out to his left and sees a U.S. fighter plane come close.

Those P-38’s, their tails were painted red. And one of ‘em, he buzzed me after the fight. When I looked over I thought I was seeing things. But that fighter pilot? He was colored. The fighter pilot looks at Jamie and salutes. Jamie retur the favor. Then the fighter plane rolls and peels off.

Then he saluted me. And I saluted back. (beat) Men who died that day... They were fathers. Husbands. Good men. Lot better than me. Jamie steeps in his survivor guilt. Ronsel hands him the bottle and he drinks. They trade a look, a bond forming.  80.

As usual, when anything bad happened, Henry was away.He And Pappy had gone to see about some hogs, so I was alone with the girls. Amanda Leigh and Isabelle making mudpies by the water pum Laura , PREGNANT, mending one of Henry’s shirts. Vera Atw barefoot with a FILLETING KNIFE, unlatches the fence, saunters into the yard. Her sweaty dress clinging to her, smile incongruous.
You need to take me to town. I’m gon’ kill Carl. Laura clocks Vera’s knife. Checks the girls who are playi on, oblivious. Laura keep panic out of her voice.
Come here Vera, come sit down and tell me what’s--
I don’t have time to sit down. He’s with her now. He’s started in on Alma, just like he did with Renie. Amanda Leigh looking scared, she takes her sister’s hand. Laura keeps panic out of her voice.
Amanda Leigh take your sister into the house. Vera directs her wild gaze on them, her knife winks in th light.
Go on around through the back. Go. Vera rocking back and forth on the heels of her feet now. knife swinging at her side.
Vera-— Vera levels the point of the knife at Laura’s neck.
You got to take me to town now.  81.
Vera honestly, I--I don’t have the keys.
I seen you driving before. Laura grasps at a lie.
And I got in trouble for it. Vera blinking, coming back to herself.

My husband took the keys away. Vera buries her face in her hands, lets out a feral howl. Laura hesitates, reaches for her. Vera steps backward out her grasp. Wanders out of the yard and back down the stre like a ghost.
They found Carl’s body lying in the road halfway to town.
Carl Atwood’s twisted body, dirt blowing across his face. Just another dead thing.
Vera had stabbed him seventeen times then gone on to Marietta and turned herself in to Sheriff Thacker. MEN heft the Carl’s corpse into a truckbed.
Florence said she’d seen her walking down Main Street, covered in blood. She said it looked like she'd bathed in it.

head_text.subj: INT. MCALLAN FARM HOUSE BEDROOM- DAY

text: (beat) But I didn’t find those details until later. I was too lost in my own misery.  82. Laura stooped, rushing through her house. She draws her bloodied hand from between her legs. Doubles over on the
What’s wrong, momma? She grunts and writhes, her hands pressed to her belly. AMANDA LEIGH (CONT’D) Momma?
I need you to be a big girl and go fetch Florence from her house. Do you remember how to get there? Amanda Leigh nods tightly. Another cramp hits and it hurt
Go. Run as fast as you can. Amanda Leigh takes off and Laura goes to the ground. A growing blood stain forms around her crotch.
Laura lays in the bed alone staring at the ceiling. Her expression is stoic and empty. She does not react when Florence enters with food and drink.
How you feeling, Ms. McAllan? (off Laura’s silence) Brought some tea to help with the cramps.
Thank you, Florence. For everything.
You know, I understand how you feeling right now, Ms. McAllan. Lost one of my babies once too. Samuel. They trade a look, two women bound by the same tragedy.
Might make you feel better to get out of this room.
Maybe tomorrow.  83. Florence lingers sits next to her. Then, after several beats, Laura’s face twists in sorrow and she weeps. Flore holds her, lets the sobs ring out.

Laura sits at the edge of the bed staring at the wall. Th Henry enters. He approaches and puts a hand on her should Laura lets it rest there for a beat, then she gently shru it off. Henry is concerned.
Laura lays in bed, curled up and depressed. She reacts wh Amanda Leigh and Isabelle enter with wildflowers.
We brought you flowers, momma.
Thank you, sweetheart. Then Isabelle holds up a molted rattlesnake skin.
This is for you, momma. We found it in the yard. Laura is repulsed but she feigns delight.
Oh my, that’s wonderful darling. I'll treasure it. (then) Go on back outside now and play. The girls scamper out and, with two fingers, Laura puts t snake skin far away.
Laura lays there, catatonic. We hold on her stillness for beat. Then the silence is broken by HAMMERING. Laura trie to ignore it, but it’s loud and incessant.
Jamie hoists Amanda Leigh high over a new wooden stall. There’s a rope attached to a bucket and pulley contraptio mounted up top.
Easy now.  84. Amanda Leigh drops lavender bunches into the bucket of wa
Momma look! Uncle Jamie’s building a shower!

(to the girls re: Laura) I thought y’all were supposed to keep a look out and tell me if she was coming. (then to Laura) Surprise! Thought you might like a little privacy every now and then. Well, what do you think? Laura stares at it, truly touched by the gesture.
I think it’s marvelous. Thank you. Laura hugs Jamie. It feels good and she sinks into him. A there’s a pin prick of light in the dark tunnel of her depression.
What’s this? Jamie and Laura quickly break the hug when Henry walks up
Your brother built us a shower.

You don’t say. Henry checks out the handy work and Laura and Jamie trade quick glance. EXT. THE MCALLAN FARM —- SHOWER - SUNSET Laura enters with a towel. The deep thrum of insects and frogs mingles with the distant sound of Amanda Leigh practicing scales on the piano in the house. As Laura gets undressed she looks up and notices large cl stained with hues of pink and gold from the setting sun. She pulls the rope and the bucket tilts and pours water i another bucket punctured with holes which creates a showe effect. Then she releases the rope and stops the water fl Jamie was thoughtful enough to put in a soap dish. In it a purple bar of soap. Laura puts the soap to her nose and draws in the scent. Lavender. She smiles and lathers up.  85. Then she pulls the rope all the way and the entire bucket starts pouring. The water is warm and it feels wonderful. It’s been so long since she had a shower. She rinses and feels so good it’s almost sensual. EXT. THE MCALLAN FARM — DAY Henry drives his tractor through thick mud. The crops hav grown-in but the field is flooded and in bad shape. Then tractor lurches and gets stuck. Henry puts it in reverse the tires just spin and dig deeper. Henry puts it in driv and tries the other direction. To no avail.
Dammit.
Still on one crutch, Hap works the wet, overgrown field. mud makes the hard work even harder. He loses his footing and falls. He gets up, more covered in mud than he was before.
Lilly May and Marlon perched on barbed wire fence posts gunning down imaginary enemies. Lilly May wears Ronsel’s helmet, Marlon wears Ronsel’s boots.
BANG BANG! You dead Nazi cracka, you dead! Marlon oversteers his “tank”.

GRRRRRR! Domp, domp domp domp. We runnin’ ‘em over! Watch your right gunner! Lilly May swivels her imaginary gun over to the right. Ju then a truck full of WHITE SHARECROPPERS rolls by. Lilly lowers her “gun”. A man tosses a soda bottle in their yar The truck rattles past.

(whispers ) Bang. You dead. INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - DAY Florence mends socks as she looks through a window watchi Ronsel sit against a tree smoking a cigarette. He’s got a thousand yard stare as he mindlessly drags and exhales.  86. Henry’s truck pulls up, Jamie behind the wheel. Ronsel ho into the passenger side. Florence doesn’t like what she sees. Then the truck pulls out and Florence watches it go

Florence leaning against the porch post, gazing into the distance. Hap hobbles out on his still-splinted leg. He l his crutches against the house, puts his arms around her, inhales her neck. Florence cradles his head.
You ain't tired?
We gotta let him go.
We're not holding him.
We are. He’s staying for us.

Maybe he wants to stay. It’s not always gonna be like this. Soon as I’m healed we’ll move outta here. We'll be okay. He’1ll be okay once he has his own place-- Florence drops her head. Hap spins her around to him, pul her into a clumsy one-legged two step. Hap hums some brok tune. Florence melts onto him.
Remember that?
You not supposed to be up on this broke leg, Hawthorne Jackson. You never let it heal, you never gon’ walk.
Why walk if I can’t dance? Hap and Florence swaying, hanging in each other’s eyes, grasping for exhausted joy.
Jamie lights a cigarette and Ronsel sips from the bottle. They're both drunk. It’s hot in here and the sunlit smoke hangs on the humid air.  87.
The silver star? Damn.
Don’t be impressed. I got it for being stupid.
What?

I almost drowned in a flood when I was a kid. Since then, baths, swimming pools, any kind of water I hate it. And this one mission I changed course so we wouldn’t be over the water so long. And, as luck would have it, we ran smack dab into some enemy flak. A lot of it. But I managed to hit the target and bring us all back.
You so scared of water you’d rather get shot at than fly over it?
Damnedest thing, ain’t it? They share a laugh and a drink, then:
You ever miss it sometimes? Being over there? I don’t mean getting shot at, but... I actually miss it.
Me too. Over there I was a Liberator. Had folks lined up on the street cheering and throwing flowers. Back here, I’m just another nigger pushing a plow.
Miss some of the guys too.
Think about ‘em every day.
Seeing different parts of the world. (smiling) (MORE)
Italian girls. English girls. Ronsel leaks a smile.
It was different over there.
(beat) You ever been with a white girl?
A few.
Well I’11 be damned.

Army gave us separate barracks, separate blood supply, separate latrines. But them European girls didn’t mind us a bit. (then) When we were in Wimbourne, English gal I never laid eyes on patted me right on the butt. Told me she was checking for a tail because the white GI's was saying we were more monkey than human. So we made sure to show ‘em just how human we were every opportunity we got.
German girls too, huh?
Yeah. Well...one in particular. Ronsel drifts with the memory of Resl, wistful.
Uh oh, I’ve seen that look before. She must’a been something special.

Yeah. She was. But that was then. And this is now. I’m back home. Right where I belong. Said with a cut of drunken sarcasm.  89. INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - NIGHT Crickets outside as Ronsel lays in bed by candlelight, wi awake. He’s gazing at Resl’s gold necklace and crucifix. Then, with resolve, he stuffs it into a small tin box nex his bed and closes the lid shut. Then he blows out the candle, still wide awake as he tries to forget her. INT. THE MCALLAN FARM —- HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT Henry snores loudly. So loudly Laura is awake. She shakes him and he stops. Then Laura settles in and tries to get comfortable. But after a few moments, Henry starts snorin again. Finally, Laura succumbs to the futility and gets u

Laura exits the house into the moonlight. She is startled when she nearly trips over Jamie, who is passed out with empty bottle of bourbon. Fully clothed and breathing heav from drink, he is peaceful and pitiful all at once.
Nonono, I can’t swim! I can’t swim! Laura turns and sees Jamie writhing in his sleep:

NO! AHHHH! AHHHHH!!!! Jamie! Jamie wake up! Laura shakes him hard. Jamie shoots to upright, eyes darting. Then he looks to Laura as the sense creeps back into him. A beat, then he starts crying. She pulls him to her and he sinks into her arms. After a few moments, Henry appears in the doorway. Neithe Laura nor Jamie notice him. Henry says nothing. He just stands there watching their embrace, jealousy in his eyes Eventually, Henry moves back into the house. Then Jamie rips himself away from Laura’s embrace:
I gotta get outta here.
Jamie... Jamie stumbles toward Henry’s car, gets in and pulls away

As Henry's car goes blazing by, swerving. INT. HENRY’S CAR (MOVING) - LATER Jamie dozing at the wheel. He awakes and jerks the truck toward the side of the road. Overshoots, and slips into a ditch. Jamie squinting, flailing, cursing as he strips th gears trying to free the truck.
Jamie shuts off the engine, slumps across the wheel cryin blubbering, incoherent. He falls asleep across the wheel. Headlights still on.

Sheriff Thacker knocking on the truck window. Jamie, red- eyed, stubbled, haggard shoulders a line of drool away. H wakes slowly, drags his sodden gaze to the window. Henry frowns over the Sheriff’s shoulder. Jamie shudders, strug with the car door. Sheriff helps rip it open. Jamie stumb into the light.
We'll get it hauled out in the morning, Henry. Jamie and Henry clamber out of the ditch in silence. Jami is hungover and haggard.
I’m sorry. Henry shakes his head in disgust.
Henry hammers repairs while Jamie finishes milking the co When Jamie stands he trips, falls and spills milk everywh Jamie laughs.
You think it’s funny spilling good milk?  91.
(slurring) Well you know what they say, no use crying over it.
No, especially when it’s somebody else's. Jamie stops grinning and turns sarcastic as he reaches in his pocket and produces some coins and crumpled bills.

I see. What do I owe you, Henry? About a dollar and a half? Let’s just say two to be safe. Jamie pushes the money at him. Henry slaps his hand away the money goes flying. A clumsy, half-hearted fist-fight.
For Christ’s sake, this ain’t about the money.
Then what do you want from me?
For you to be a man!
One pail of spilled milk and I’m not a man?
You're sure not acting like one. Disappear for days at a time doing whatever you damn well please. And when you are here, you’re drunk.
I don’t answer to you.
You do when you live in my house and work on my farm.
Oh, well I’m real sorry about that Mr. Boss man. But don’t take it out on me because your little farmer dream ain’t working. Ain’t my fault your crops are getting flooded out.  92.
Well you sure as hell ain’t helping matters. It’s like having another goddamn child to look after.
You need to open your eyes, big brother. You’re so busy walking around here like God almighty, so wrapped up in yourself and your damn farm you can’t even see your own wife is miserable.
Watch your mouth.
Or what? Henry clenches his fists and squares up. Jamie stands his ground. But Henry restrains himself.
Know what? You be whatever kind of man you want. Just go do it someplace else.
Fine, I’1l go to town.

I don’t mean just for the night. In the morning I’m going to Greenville for a few days to see about some livestock. I’11 expect you gone when I get back. They hold a look, neither man seeing clearly through the of anger and pride. Then Henry leaves Jamie in his wake.
As Jamie packs his things, frustrated, angry. He reacts w Laura knocks at his open doorway.
Hi there, will you be here for supper tonight?
(re: the packed bags) Are you going someplace?
Out west probably. Gotta buddy from the war who lives in Los Angeles.
Los Angeles? Jamie, what are you talking about?
He didn’t tell you?
Who didn’t tell me what?
Henry. He kicked me out.
What?
He asked me to leave. I probably had it coming.
That can’t be. He’s just sore about the wreck. Let me talk to him.
No, Laura. He’s more than just sore. And it’s probably for the best.
So just like that? You up and leave? Were you even planning on saying good-bye?
Of course. First bus out doesn’t leave ‘til two.
What about the girls? This will break their little hearts.
I‘1l talk to them.
Jamie keeps packing. The suddenness of this new reality i bitter prospect for Laura.
Does your father know?
I'll go down to the river and find the girls. And Pappy... I’1l just leave him a note.
You don’t need to go, Jamie. When Henry cools off he’1l listen to me. Jamie stops packing for a moment and stares at the floor. Then he looks at her, so much hurt in his eyes.
Laura, I can’t stay here. I feel like I’m suffocating. I can’t explain it...

You don’t need to. Laura runs her hand along his suitcase and wishes she cou run away with him. Jamie tamps his pain, tired of being pathetic. Laura moves to him, close. They gaze at each other for a very long beat, neither wanting to say goodby Then with alarming swiftness, Laura grabs Jamie and kisse him. Deeply. Hungrily. Then suddenly he pushes her away. Both of them breathe heavily, their hearts racing. Then Jamie pulls her close and they kiss again. Clothes get to off as they tumble onto the bed. Jamie and Laura devour e other. INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - DAY Florence, Hap, Marlon and Lilly May clean up after breakf Ronsel enters, haggard and sleepless.
It’s half past nine. You just now getting up? Ronsel shrugs and nods.
You just gon’ lay around all day? While your brothers and sisters work? What’s wrong with you--  95.
You got a letter. Says it’s all the way from Germany.
What? Hap hands over a worn envelope that’s traveled a long way Ronsel snatches it.
Who’s Resl Braun?
Someone I knew. And Ronsel heads out the front door.
Where you going now? Ronsel!
I’1l be back.

The grey horizon hints at a coming storm. Ronsel walks along, a swirl of emotion, shaking his head in disbelief he reads the letter. Then he reacts to the rising sound of an APPROACHING TRUC He quickly shoves the letter into his pockets. The truck moving fast. The glint from the windshield prevents us fr seeing the driver. But we hear the engine rev higher as h steps on the gas. Ronsel moves to the shoulder of the road. But the truck swerves in his direction and bears down on him. Ronsel ru and dives into a ditch just as the truck rumbles up and s to a fast stop. Then, surprisingly, Jamie tumbles out, laughing and drunk. He’s got a bottle of whiskey and he looks like absolute hell.
You should’a seen the look on your face.
It ain’t funny.
Actually, my friend, it was indeed.  96. Ronsel gets up and brushes himself off. Jamie is still smiling. Then soon, Ronsel can’t help but smile too.
You're crazy you know that, right?
Can’t argue with that. No, sir. Jamie takes a pull from the bottle and plops to the groun mess. Ronsel sees the state he’s in.
Hey. Is something the matter? Jamie gets quiet and picks at the label on the bottle.
What’s the worst thing you ever did?
(after a beat) That lady I told you about. The one at the prison camp.

No, I mean something that hurt somebody real bad. And you knew it was gonna hurt ‘em, but you did it anyway. This time Ronsel gets quiet for a long beat. Then he pull out the letter and a photo and hands it to Jamie.
Leaving her. Jamie looks at the picture then reads the letter. Then he reacts and smiles:
Well, I’ll be. Congratulations. You're a father.
His name’s Franz.

Franz. That’s a good name. (then) So that’s the German girl.  97. Ronsel nods and we finally see the photo. It is of Resl holding a swaddled baby. Jamie hands the photo back to Ronsel and holds up the bottle:
Well this calls for a celebration. Here’s to Franz. Jamie takes a swig and hands Ronsel the bottle.
To Franz. Then Ronsel takes a drink and gives the bottle back to Ja
So what the hell are you gonna do?
I have no idea. She wants me to go to Germany.
Long way off. Ronsel nods, he knows. Jamie stares into the distance as Ronsel stares at Franz. Then:
What about you? What’s the worst thing you ever done? Jamie looks at him, his mind on Laura and their tryst. Bu Jamie smiles and covers:
Who me? I’m a saint.

Oh yeah, I bet. Then there’s a distant THUNDER RUMBLE. The clouds on the horizon are getting darker. Jamie kills the whiskey bottl and tosses it into the ditch. INT. HENRY’S PICK-UP TRUCK - DAY Jamie and Ronsel pass a new bottle and sing in unison:
It don't mean a thing if it ain't got that swing. (MORE )
Doo-ah, doo-ah, doo-ah, doo-ah, doo- ah, doo-ah, doo-ah. It don't mean a thing all you got -- They both react to an approaching car and stop singing.

Oh shit, put your head down. Ronsel ducks. The dust makes it hard to see but the road narrow and soon they pass the oncoming car. Orris drives Pappy rides shotgun. Jamie looks forward and Ronsel keeps his head low. Pappy and Orris crane their necks as the vehicles cross.
You think they saw us?
Don’t know. INT. HENRY’S PICK-UP TRUCK - DAY Jamie and Ronsel pull up to the Jackson’s shack, both dru
Here we are. (beat) I'll be leaving town soon and... Well, good luck to you. You’ve been a friend. I want you to know that.
Yeah? Well I want you to know it too. You’re one of the good ones. Jamie hesitates to accept this truth. Ronsel extends a ha Jamie graps it, they shake hard.
Hope you find a way to your...to your boy...to your... family.
Take care of yourself.
You too. They hold a look, friends. Jamie extends a hand. They sha  99. INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - DAY The RUMBLE OF DISTANT THUNDER. Florence flinches when Ron enters, wobbly and high.
Hi, Momma. She watches him, wants to hug him ask him where he’s been But what comes out is:
You hungry?
No. Where is everybody?

Went up to church. Late service. Ronsel plops onto his cot. Florence wants to talk to him, help him, but he seems so unreachable. Ronsel reaches into his pocket and pulls out the envelope from Resl. He reaches inside and finds nothing. Where’s t letter and the photo? Brow furrowed, he stands and rifles through his other pockets. Not there. Oh shit. Rising panic. He lost it.
Goddammit... No, no, no.
What is it son?
You seen a letter?
The letter from Germany?
Yes.
Oh God. Let’s just wait. Don’t fret. Wait till your father-- Ronsel busts out of the shack and back into the night.
Ronsel? Ronsel!  100.

The threat of thunder has turned into reality of pounding rain. Ronsel runs to the spot where he told Jamie about t letter. He looks around desperately. He finds the empty whiskey bottle with the label Jamie picked off.
Laura is in the kitchen. Amanda Leigh and Isabelle are on the floor playing with building blocks. Pappy lingers by window, anxiously waiting.
Goddammit, where is he?
(re: the girls) Mind your language, please.
Just like him. Thinking only of himself. (then) There he is. Outside the truck pulls up, weaving badly. Jamie gets out and stumbles to the house.
Drunk again. Jamie enters, rumpled, wet and smiling.
Well, hello, dear family.
Uncle Jamie!
Let him dry off first.
Who in the hell was that with you in the truck?
Hello, son. I’m glad to see you.
On the road. When I saw you driving. Who was that?  101.
Ronsel Jackson. What's it to you?
You care to tell me why that nigger was sitting right next to you like you was two peas in a pod?
Because I was giving him a ride.
He can ride in the back.
He can ride wherever I say. Anything else?
Gimmie a cigarette. I’m out. Jamie stares at him for a beat then pulls out an old pack Lucky Strikes. Pappy snatches them. It’s empty.
You ain’t worth a damn, you know that?
Yeah. I do. Jamie wobbles.
Look at mister big war hero. Nothing but a drunk.
Just go.
Want him all to yourself huh, gal? Too bad he’s too liquored up to be any good to you.
I beg your pardon.
I’ve seen the way you sniff after him --
Pappy.  102.
Henry may be too thick to notice, but I ain’t.

Rain as Ronsel trudges up the road. Then he reacts to the crescendo of approaching cars. He turns and sees two sets headlights approaching fast. Ronsel jumps down into the ditch. But instead of passing, the cars pull up and stop. Ronsel is a bit blinded by the headlights and the rain. But soon several figures in whit sheets and hoods pile out of the cars and rush at him. Ronsel runs but they are on him like a pack of dogs. He fights and struggles, landing several hard punches. But h outnumbered.
Rain beats on the roof as Jamie sleeps on his cot. A beat then he is poked awake by Pappy’s cane. Jamie bolts up, startled to see Pappy. Orris Stokes and the Sheriff are behind him in white robes.
What the hell’s going on?
Put your boots on and come with us.

Hard rain. Orris Stokes’ car pulls up and stops among som other parked cars. Jamie, Pappy, and Orris Stokes get out and move towards the saw mill. We can see torch lights coming from inside the mill. As they go, the Sheriff and Stokes don their white hoods. This gives Jamie pause and stops. But Stokes shoves him along.
Go on. They open the door to the saw mill and enter.

Inside are a group of men in KKK garb. In the middle of t mill is Ronsel. He has a burlap sack over his head, a noo around his neck and his hands tied behind him. He’s strun up from a rafter, his tip-toes barely touching the ground One of the white hoods holds the other end of the rope. Another man (DEX) stands nearby with a shotgun.  103.
What’s going on here, Pappy?
Shut up.
(re: Ronsel) Take it off. Dex moves to Ronsel and yanks the sack off his head. As h eyes adjust to the light we see that Ronsel has been beat
Good Lord. Turn him loose.
I said shut up.
Like hell I will. Turn him loose, dammit. Stokes pulls his pistol and levels it at Jamie:
You best listen, son.
I ain’t your son. And I suggest you either use that thing or point it elsewhere. Jamie readies lunge at Stokes.
Jamie!

Bring forth the evidence. One of the white hoods moves forward and brings out the letter and the photograph from Resl. Both Jamie and Ronse see it and sink. The white hood hands it to Pappy. SHERIFF THACKER (CONT’D) You know why you’re here, nigger? (off Ronsel’s silence) I asked you a question. Ronsel stays silent. Sheriff throws a nod to Orris who wa over to Ronsel and slugs him with a left and then a right the ribs. The thuds from the blows force grunts from Rons  104. Jamie winces. But Ronsel stays as cool. He will not show them his fear. Pappy walks up to Ronsel and shows him the letter and the picture of Resl and Franz. Ronsel eyes the photo. SHERIFF THACKER (CONT’D) Did you rut with this woman?
We know you did it, nigger. We just want to hear you say it. The white hood holding the rope jerks it.
Go on! Say it!
What the hell do you fellows care about some Kraut whore?
Shut your mouth, nigger lover.
You knew about it. Found the letter in the truck after you gave him a ride.

Those Fraulein cunts got a lot of our boys killed. If Ronsel here left her with a little half-breed bundle of joy to remind her of it, I call it justice. Jamie’s logic lands for a moment and there’s hope.
Oh you’re good, pretty boy. Too bad you’re full of shit.
How do you even know that Ronsel here, is the father?
Says so right there in the letter.
That doesn’t mean a damn thing.  105.
Well, let’s ask him, why don’t we? (to Ronsel re: the photo) Are you the father of this, I won’t call it a child, this... abomination?
Answer him! The noose tightens. Ronsel won’t deny his own son and he Manages to choke out the word:
Yes...
Leviticus 19:19. “Ye shall keep my statutes. Thou shalt not let thy cattle gender with a diverse kind. Thou shalt not sow thy field with mingled seed." The penalty for abomination is death.
Have you all lost your damn minds?! Killing a decorated soldier over an enemy whore?! The man fought for Patton for Godsakes --
That’s enough --
You turn him loose now and maybe I won't go to the law. Otherwise, I swear, you better kill us both. Stokes can’t believe the nerve of Jamie and he moves towa him with the gun.

You gonna betray your own blood over a nigger?! Pappy tries to stand between Stokes and Jamie, but Jamie shoves him out of the way. Stokes points the gun at Jamie Jamie steps up and puts the gun barrel to his own forehea

Do it. Go on.  105A. The entire room hangs on the tension for a long beat. The quick as a cat, Jamie swipes the gun with one hand and PUNCHES Stokes in the mouth with the other. Stokes’s head snaps back and he stumbles backwards and falls. Jamie quickly turns to Dex who has the shotgun.  106.
Drop it, Dex! Dex hesitates and Jamie cocks the hammer.
He’s bluffing. And half drunk besides.
Shut up, old man.
Point the gun at the nigger. Pappy moves right into Jamie’s eye line, blocking his sho
He won’t shoot. He don’t have the balls to kill a man up close. Do you, son? Dex points the shotgun at Ronsel. Pappy steps closer to Jamie.
Stop right there. I’m warning you.

You not gon’ kill your Pappy. Then one of the white hoods charges at Jamie. Jamie turns and shoots him in the leg. But that was enough to give th others a chance to rush in. Jamie squeezes off another shot that misses before he get tackled. In the subsequent melee, they somehow manage to wrest the gun from Jamie’s hands. But Jamie punches, kicks and gives everything he’s got, fighting like a cornered animal. But soon, they overwhelm him. And they proceed to beat the shit out of him. Jamie and Ronsel lock eyes for a moment during the beatin Then a kick to the head from Stokes. CUT TO BLACK. PAPPY’S VOICE FADES IN, echo-y and distant.  107.
Wake up! Jamie! Wake up dammit!

Jamie is awakened by a bucket of cold rain water. He is bruised, blurry and dazed. But as focus restores he sees mass of white hoods staring down at him. Among the hoods is Pappy’s face. Jamie recoils and tries push him away but his hands are tied behind his back. Pap yanks him upright and props him against the wall. Jamie s that Ronsel now hangs from a cross-beam, naked and bloodi
You make one more wrong move these boys are liable to kill you.
(re: Jamie) What do we do with him?
I told you already. He won’t talk. Ain’t that right, son?
(re: Ronsel) Just let him go.
You ain’t exactly in a position to make demands.
He won't go to the law. Not if we make him a part of it.
How?
Nigger still needs to be punished. You let my son, there, decide how.
(after a beat) Alright then. What’ll it be?
I won't do it.  108.
You don’t want him killed? Then decide his punishment.
No. Stokes unsheathes a HUNTING KNIFE:
You will. Or I will. Dex moves to Ronsel and puts the shotgun to Ronsel’s head
I'll give you a choice. His eyes. His tongue. Or his balls. Choose. (off Jamie’s silence) Choose godammit!
No...
Dex --
Alright! Alright... Jamie locks eyes with Ronsel. This is an impossible choic
Which is it, boy? Jamie's head drops and he mumbles something.

Speak up. As Turpin leans in the RISING MUSIC and the SOUNDS OF THE STORM OUTSIDE TAKE OVER.
